docs.lead_paragraph: Aides say Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, will lean on President Obama to arbitrate the issues in the health care legislation that threaten to divide Democrats.

headline.main: Reid the Quarterback May Call on Obama to Referee
headline.print_headline: Reid the Quarterback May Call on Obama to Referee

docs.snippet: Aides say Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, will lean on President Obama to arbitrate the issues in the health care legislation that threaten to divide Democrats.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Much of the important discussion over changing health care has been a travesty, starting with absurd notions of death panels and including scare tactics like saying the government will ration treatments.
docs.snippet: Much of the important discussion over changing health care has been a travesty, starting with absurd notions of death panels and including scare tactics like saying the government will ration treatments.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats proposing an overhaul of the American health care system have gotten themselves locked in a box around the question of affordability. This is not the question of whether the proposed health care legislation is affordable for taxpayers and the federal government -- an issue that seemed to be answered when the Congressional Budget Office said the Senate Finance Committee's bill would eventually help reduce federal budget deficits.
docs.abstract: Affordability is still vexing issue in debate over health care overhaul; Democratic supporters of reform are facing potentially serious political consequences if they fail to deliver bill that allows people with moderate incomes to afford health insurance; affordability is especially important since proposed legislation would require all Americans to obtain health insurance; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Democrats proposing an overhaul of the American health care system have gotten themselves locked in a box around the question of affordability.      This is not the question of whether the proposed health care legislation is affordable for taxpayers...

docs.lead_paragraph: A restaurant owner, squeezed by a slump in sales and growing debt to his landlord, discontinues his health insurance. A contractor decides not to replace a member of his small crew who quit. An industrial bicycle maker starts selling to universities, prisons and zoos. For a quintet of small businesses that The New York Times has been tracking for the past year, the persistent recession has hurt some more than others. As fall began, some cautious optimism about a recovery crept into recent interviews conducted by Patrick McGeehan, Erik Olsen and Gabriel Johnson. Georgette Blau

headline.main: Small Business Owners Are Coping, And Feeling Grateful for the Bright Spots

docs.abstract: Follow-up interviews with five small business owners around New York City who are being tracked by The New York Times to see how persistent recession has affected them; some cautious optimism is expressed; business owners are Georgette Blau of On Location Tours, Wayne Sosin of Worksman Cyles, Mouhamad Shami of Alfanoose Restaurant, Ruben Villasante of V & V Construction and Michael Menna of Menna's Quality Meats and Salumeria photos (M)
docs.snippet: For five small business owners in New York, the conditions are still rough  but these entrepreneurs are grateful for a few bright spots.

multimedia.credit: Part IV in a series following several small businesses in the New York area to see how they are handing the recession.
multimedia.caption: Small Business and the Economic Crisis

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama pressed his case for health care reform on Saturday night at a Congressional Black Caucus awards dinner, saying, "The cup of endurance runs over."

headline.main: Obama and the Black Caucus, Together Again

docs.abstract: President Obama's remarks at the annual Congressional Black Caucus awards dinner were well-received among the star-studded crowd.
docs.snippet: President Obama's remarks at the annual Congressional Black Caucus awards dinner were well-received among the star-studded crowd.

docs.lead_paragraph: The talk in Washington continues to revolve around the revelation that Iran has been hiding a secret uranium enrichment program. The first diplomatic talks between the United States and Iran in 30 years are scheduled to begin Thursday in Geneva, and President Obama plans to tell the county that it must open the clandestine plant to international inspectors "within weeks," The Times's David Sanger and William J. Broad report this morning.

headline.main: Early Word: What to Do About Iran

docs.abstract: The talk in Washington continues to revolve around the revelation that Iran has been hiding a secret uranium enrichment program.
docs.snippet: The talk in Washington continues to revolve around the revelation that Iran has been hiding a secret uranium enrichment program.

docs.lead_paragraph: What the Republicans aren’t saying — and what the Democrats clearly aren’t saying enough — is that Medicare coverage should improve under health care reform.
